title: 114_s2712
content: The Act may be cited as the "Combat-Injured Veterans Tax Fairness Act of 2016". Congress finds that approximately 10,000 to 11,000 retired individuals from the Armed Forces for medical reasons each year, including those separated for combat-related injuries. Congress acknowledges the sacrifice of veterans with combat-related injuries by excluding severance pay from taxable income. Since 1991, the Secretary of Defense has wrongly withheld taxes from severance pay for wounded veterans, denying them rightful compensation intended by Congress. Many veterans owed redress are beyond the statutory limit. Many veterans are owed redress for taxes wrongly withheld from severance pay, beyond the statutory period to file amended tax returns. Many veterans are owed redress for taxes wrongly withheld from severance pay, beyond the statutory period to file amended tax returns. The restoration of amounts improperly withheld for tax purposes from severance payments to veterans with combat-related injuries is addressed in Section 3. The Secretary of Defense must identify severance payments made after January 17, 1991, compute payments not considered gross income, and provide notice to individuals affected. The Secretary of Defense must identify severance payments made after January 17, 1991, compute payments not considered gross income, and provide notice with instructions for filing amended tax returns to recover improperly withheld amounts for tax purposes. Additionally, the 3-year period for filing a claim for credit or refund related to a specified overpayment under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is extended. The limitation on the expiration of a specified overpayment shall not be before 1 year after filing the information return. The allowable credit or refund amount is determined without considering tax paid within the specified period. A specified overpayment refers to an overpayment related to a severance payment. The Secretary of Defense must ensure that tax withholding is not applied to severance payments that are not considered gross income. Additionally, a report to Congress is required. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within one year of the enactment of this Act, detailing the identification process and actions taken. The report must include the number of individuals identified, the total amount withheld for tax purposes from severance payments, and plans for implementing section 4. The Senate and House Committees on Armed Services, Veterans' Affairs, and Finance/Ways and Means will receive a report from the Secretary of Defense within one year of this Act, detailing identification process, actions taken, number of individuals identified, total amount withheld for tax purposes from severance payments, and plans for implementing section 4.
